msItem.title: Petition (விண்ணப்பம் viṇṇappam) by the Pondicherry potters, with census of the Pondicherry potters

supportDesc.condition: Very good state of preservation, except that all the leaves are broken into two halves. This damage seems to have occured long ago as the leaves, which originally had one hole only for the thread, have been pierced with three more holes, so as to accommodate two threads, also passing through the woodcovers (both pierced with four holes). U3, f[1] is truncated, as approximately 10 cm of the leaf is missing on the left edge of page.

binding.p: Woodcovers apparently fabricated in the BnF.

origin.origDate: 1793. See U1, f[1]r, c1 and U2, f1r, c1.

body.p: This document is basically a petition by the potters of Pondicherry written in the presence of the French civil servant Daniel Lescallier, “commissaire civil”. It opens with an introduction (U1), in which the key-term viṇṇappam occurs (f[1]r, c3, 3). Then comes a census of the potters of Pondicherry (U2), most residing in Nellittōppu, while others are stated to reside in Piḷḷaicāvaṭi and Reṭṭipāḷaiyam. Finally comes the petition proper (U3). The potters explain that they have been considered as Valaṅkai (a right-hand group, by opposition to left-hand groups) in the Pondicherry and surrounding region. They remit, it seems, the judgement about their group belonging (Valaṅkai or commonness) to the above-mentioned French civil servant Daniel Lescallier. Four mēstiris ("overseers") are designated and the list of their names is given. The potters seem finally to declare that they will do whatever the toraikaḷ (i.e. tuṟaikaḷ, “the lord” or the “lords”), that is, Lescallier or the mēstiris, order them or decide.
The bundle, a single-text manuscript, contains between the two woodcovers:
U1: 1 folio, unfoliated = petition introduction, by hand n° 1. Unblackened. 1 page (verso blank). The lay-out is in columns.
U2: 3 folios, Tamil foliation 2–3 (f1 not explicitly foliated) = census of Pondicherry potters, by hand n° 2 (?). 5 pages (f3v blank). The lay-out is in columns.
U3: 1 folio, unfoliated = petition proper, by hand n° 3 (?). Unblackened. 2 pages. The lay-out is in columns.

Abbreviations. c = column, f = folio, lm = left margin, r = recto, rm = right margin, U = unit (codicological and/or textual), v = verso.

Unmarked puḷḷi, ō, and ē restored. Conjectural (whether the text is not clearly legible or the character is ambigous, e.g. kāl or length of o and e) readings between parentheses. Alternative readings between parentheses separated by slash. Lost or entirely illegible character: "?". Lacuna of unknown extent: [...]. Crossed-out character: "X". Conjectural restoration of lost or entirely illegible between square brackets. Uppercase for initial vowels (in excerpts only). Unquoted text represented by (...). Grantha letters in bold. Symbols/Abbreviations made explicit, between curly brackets: {pcs} = piḷḷaiyār cuḻi, short form; {pcl} = piḷḷaiyār cuḻi, long form, that is, with long horizontal stroke towards right; {varuṣam}, {mācam}, {tēti}; {line-filler}. Unfoliated folio number between square brackets, e.g. "f[1]r". Numerals normalised to decimal notation, e.g. "1121" not "1000 1 100 2 10 1". Hyphen occasionaly used to mark in-word components. Hyphen systematically used at the end of a line when the line-beginning is within a word or within a cīr. Sandhi split to the minimum: overshort u occasionally restored as an apostrophe.
